children.subject: I'll check out those classes, thank you so much!

Hi, I actually took your fall 2021 schedule last semester, but minus 126, plus 170 and another tech along with recruiting and I felt it was very doable. If you are interested in the more EE side, I would recommend the robotics classes (106a and 106b)
I'm looking forward to taking it in the spring :) thank you so much!

+1 on EE120 in the Spring with Babak. Absolute best class I've ever taken at Cal with the best blackboard lecturer I've ever had. I took it with him Spring 2019 and the lectures were ALWAYS filled and fully attended for 2 hours because he was that amazing. The workload is pretty low I would say, 6 medium-length homeworks and 5 short python labs. No final exam as he doesn't like having conflicts so he does 3 midterms where the final midterm is right before RRR week. You can check out his webcasted videos here: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLkFD6_40KJIwfL-CQnMHVPI_QjlF8mW2O

<md>126 has uses beyond ML. If you're interested in theory, it is recommended you take this course. Be a little careful with graduate courses. It's more important you finish all the undergrad courses before you start looking at graduate offerings. You will not only have a less difficult time but it's likely you'll get a better understanding of the material if you have solid fundamentals. As for recruiting, it is helpful to nail down the courses that you'd actually find useful for recruiting. For example, if you want to go into hardware engineering, taking 151 might be a good idea. If you want to do quant, then taking 126 is a good idea. If you want to do system programming, taking 162 is a good idea.</md>

thank you so much! next semester I'm thinking about taking cs61c, math 53, and 1 more tech (deciding between ee105, 106a, 120, or 126). would you recommend taking ee120 sooner just so I can see if it is something I am interested in or waiting until spring 2022 to take it with Babak? Also that's really cool that you work with medical devices!! I was wondering if you had any advice how to get into that as a career (in terms of classes and if we should need more edu after undergrad) and how you are currently liking it as a job. thank you so much and your response was super helpful!!

So, one big issue is that it seems that not many courses are being offered in the fall (period): https://www2.eecs.berkeley.edu/Scheduling/EE/schedule-draft.html

I am of the opinion that everyone claiming to know EECS should take EE 120, just because the content is so fundamental to EE especially and also finds many applications in other domains (e.g. graphics and image processing). It's also "just right" in terms of conceptual difficulty and workload, so, yeah, I'd take it as soon as is feasible for you. 

Among the classes you listed for that last slot in your schedule, they all seem to have around the same workload, with 126 lying on the heavier side. If they're all of similar interest to you, I'd recommend taking whichever works best with your schedule, to be honest. This comes with the implicit encouragement that you should be going to lecture and office hours in your upper divs for sure so that you will have a way of getting letters of recommendation in the future. 

One thing I didn't mention in my last comment was that 126 with Kannan Ramchandran was the best-taught class I have ever taken (and I took 120 the same semester as Anon Atom). It's literally what comes to mind when the concept of a stereotypically picture-perfect college lecture is brought up in conversation or whatever. I would specifically recommend that you take 126 with Kannan (and put a lot of effort into it as well). 

Maybe I oversold myself, but I'm a grad student that is advised by a circuits prof in BWRC and a prof at UCSF. I have no BioE background other than the BioE research I did as an undergrad in Prof. Michel Maharbiz's research group here (produced a few of the founders of Neuralink; also Prof. Maharbiz spun out his own startup, which was recently sold for a couple hundred million dollars), and the fact that I've read many papers regarding medical devices as a result. I kind of stumbled onto the field and have no real sentimental attachment to it or anything, but I definitely always feel like I am working on something that can change lives, and that is pretty satisfying, I suppose. However, it is not a field for people that aren't comfortable with animal experiments. I'm a vegetarian and needed to explicitly come to terms with this on my own.

In terms of getting involved in this sort of thing, I think it depends a little bit on whether you want to focus more on the "medical" part or the "devices" part. For the former, and for applications such as prosthetics, I think BioE classes can impart real value and help inform your design process as an engineer. For the latter, especially for miniature integrated systems (what I work on), most of the real design work is at the circuit and fabrication level, so specific medical knowledge isn't always necessary. I myself got into this sort of thing just because it's a hot area of research among circuits people, and I like circuits. 

If you'd like to be a "devices" person, like me, I'd recommend diving deep in the circuits and signal processing coursework I mentioned and then sending a cold email to grad students in whichever BSAC or BWRC lab is doing work that appeals to you so that you can get involved in research. Similar advice goes for the other case, although I can't necessarily give lab advice (although I have heard that Prof. Steven Conolly is very nice). 

In terms of career outlook, I'd aim to do a 5th Year MS and then dip to Verily or Neuralink or another prosperous biotech firm, at least if you feel like "getting your hands dirty". You could also consider doing a PhD, as I am, which is a financially poor investment, in general, but can empower you to play a bigger role in design after you graduate (with the PhD). In biotech, there isn't really a shortage of PhDs, so they get the cool innovative work by default (that's also what doing a PhD is supposed to be about anyway). 

Hope this helps! :^)
thank you so much this was really helpful!!

I was late to this post but @Averal I just wanted to ask whether I would need a 5th year MS to do medical devices since I'm interested in that area as well even though I have no knowledge in "medical" at all as much as devices. Money isn't really an issue for me but I don't really enjoy research from my experience working in a FPGA lab in the fall. Maybe it sucks since it was online but I'm not sure if I wanna do MS or research-related things at all. 

Also since the scheduling is kinda a mess, is it okay to skip 105 into 140 for Fall 2021? (as I wanna try out analog design and 140 isn't offered in Spring) I've taken and done well in 16B (A+), 120 (A), 123 (A/A- rn), 151 (P for lecture/A for lab), 127 (B+), 128 (A), 106A/B (A/taking rn).

Also is there any other EE classes that might be nice to add/you recommend (was looking at 130/149/147/143 but wasn't sure)? I saw you wrote about how 126 is the class to take and I plan to take it with Ramchandran in Spring. 

Also what companies should I look towards to apply in general for biotech in general in SF?

I just wanted to chime in and say that I had (and have) no interest in ML, and EECS 126 was one of my favorite classes as an undergrad. Historically, the class was actually designed for an emphasis on digital communications, but this department as a whole has kind of divested itself from digital communications (e.g. EE 121 is not offered anymore). In any case, the concepts covered in EECS 126 are relevant to literally everything in EECS and most other things as well.

In general, I'd recommend having taken Math 53 before taking EECS 126 just so that doing 2D integrals is familiar to you (for joint distributions). But, if joint distributions are still covered in CS 70 and you were able to internalize that well enough, then it might not be a problem. 

One of my other favorite classes was EE 123, which is about digital signal processing (and also ham radio). I'd recommend taking EE 120 with Babak (the guy with the clown horn) and then taking EE 123 with Miki Lustig (the guy who begins every lecture by screaming "wooo"). But both classes are great and a lot of fun to take with any instructor. 

If you like electricity, you can consider taking other courses like EE 105 (intro circuits)/140 (analog circuits)/ 113 (power circuits)/ 137AB (power systems)/ 130 (device physics) and EECS 151 (digital circuits). I'd imagine that, if you're taking BioE classes, you might be interested in medical devices - 105 or 151 would be the place to start with that (my job is medical devices).

history.content:
Hello! This post will probably be a little disorganized but I'm not sure on what upper division classes to take/what I'm interested in. I was considering taking EE120 because I kind of enjoyed EE16b and I heard it was a recommended class. I'm also in CS170 right now and I sort of enjoy it as well, so I was thinking about eventually taking CS270 or some other theory class when they are offered. I also heard EECS 126 was a recommended class, but I feel like most people who take it are interested in ML so I'm not too sure if I would have a reason to take it. I also wanted to fit Math 53 in here as well because of EE120 and I'm also interested in taking some upperdiv BioE classes (listed as prereq).

My current plan:
Fall 2021: CS61c, Math 53, EE126 (unsure about this workload because of recruiting)
Spring 2021: EE120, CS 162, a BioE class
Fall 2022 - Spring 2023: depending on what interests I want to pursue


Sorry if this is a big jumble of stuff but mainly I was wondering if anyone can provide any insights on their experiences with any of the classes listed + their motivation for taking the class and any advice on  the class/tentative schedule is appreciated! Also I'm not sure if I should be taking more classes in one area instead of trying a little bit of different topics. Thank you so much!!
history.subject: Upper division EECS/CS classes
